by 1968 the haze code which delineated
what violent sex and themes could be
depicted on American screens was all but
gone and that same year the Night of the
Living Dead birthed a new age of
independent cinema and the zombie genre
itself speaking of birth Rosemary's Baby
also came out in 68 capping a decade of
memorable psychological thrillers like
the Innocents and whatever happened to
Baby Jane for this list we included
titles with at least 10 reviews and
according to their score and average
review are ranked by adjusted Tomato
Meter so get ready for some classic
screams as we count down our list of the
best horror movies of the 1960s

taking its title from an archaic
Japanese word meaning ghost story this
Anthology adapts four folk tales a
penniless Samurai marries for money with
tragic results a man stranded in a
blizzard is saved by Yuki the snow
Maiden but his rescue comes at a cost
blind musician hoichi is forced to
perform for an audience of ghosts an
author relates the story of a samurai
who sees another Warrior's reflection in
his teacup starring katsuo Nakamura
rentaro Mikuni Keiko Kishi and directed
by masaki Kobayashi critics say
exquisitely designed and fastidiously
ornate masaki kobayashi's ambitious
Anthology cuaden operates less as a
frightening example of horror and more
as a meditative tribute to Japanese
folklore

number nine persona famed Sage stress
Elizabeth Vogler suffers a moment of
blankness during her performance and the
next day lapses into total silence
advised by her doctor to take time off
to recover from what appears to be an
emotional breakdown Elizabeth goes to a
beach house on the Baltic Sea with only
Alma a nurse his company over the next
several weeks is Alma struggles to reach
her mute patient the two women find
themselves experiencing a strange
emotional convergence starring Bibi
Anderson Liv Ullman Gunner Yorn Strand
and directed by ingmar Bergman critics
say arguably bergman's finest film
Persona explores a human condition with
intense curiosity immense technical
skill and beguiling warmth

number eight whatever happened to Baby
Jane Jane Hudson is an aging child star
left to care for her wheelchair-bound
sister Blanche also a former child
actress stuck living together in a
mansion in old Hollywood Blanche plots
to get even with Jane for the car crash
it left her crippled years earlier but
Jane is desperate to keep Blanche
imprisoned as she plans a new rise to
fame and tries to hide blanche's
existence from doctors visitors and
neighbors while she devises a way to get
rid of her sister starring Betty Davis
Joan Crawford Victor buono and directed
by Robert Aldrich critics say whatever
happened to Baby Jane combines
Powerhouse acting Rich atmosphere and
absorbing melodrama in service of a
taught Thriller with thought-provoking
subtexts who was that at the door

Number Four Eyes Without a Face
Dr Jen essiers riddled with Guild after
an accident that he caused disfigures
the face of his daughter the once
beautiful Christian who Outsiders
believe is dead Dr Jenna Sierra along
with accomplice and laboratory assistant
Louise kidnaps young women and brings
them to the genesier mansion after
rendering his victims unconscious Dr
Jenna Sierra removes her faces and
attempts to graft them onto Christians
starring Pierre brosor Elita volley Edis
Cobb and directed by George franju
critics say a horrific tale of guilt and
Obsession Eyes Without a Face is just as
chilling and poetic today as it was when
it first released

number three Rosemary's Baby
why fish Rosemary Woodhouse and her
struggling actor husband guy moved to a
New York City apartment building with an
ominous reputation and odd neighbors
Roman and Minnie Costa vet when Rosemary
becomes pregnant she becomes
increasingly isolated and the Diabolical
truth is revealed only after Rosemary
gives birth starring Mia Farrow John
cassavetz Ruth Gordon and directed by
Roman Polanski critics say Rosemary's
Baby is a frightening tale of Satanism
and pregnancy that is even more
disturbing than it sounds thanks to
convincing and committed performances by
Mia Farrow and Ruth Gordon

and finally number one psycho Phoenix
secretary Marion crane on the lamb after
stealing 40 Grand from her employer in
order to run away with her boyfriend Sam
Loomis is overcome by exhaustion during
a heavy rainstorm traveling on the back
roads to avoid the police she stops for
the night at the ramshackle Bates Motel
and meets the polite but highly shrunk
proprietor Norman Bates a young man with
an interest in Taxidermy and a difficult
relationship with his mother starring
Anthony Perkins Janet Lee Vera Miles and
directed by Alfred Hitchcock critics say
Infamous for a shower scene but Immortal
for its contribution to the horror genre
because psycho was filmed with tact
Grace and art Hitchcock didn't just
create modern horror he validated it
